message: So annoying.  I wish everyone would switch to Word documents.  --Seriously, though, plain text or markdown is fine with me.
I'm using markdown for almost everything now
however, not showing up in github is annoying
ReStructured text is the way to go for me
Drives me crazy when someone formats a README with some format, then leaves the extension off so GitHub renders it at plan text.
@bitprophet, yeah I use markdown for prose. ReST for technical documentation
I believe that's how it's already handled? Not sure if I'm misremembering.
I guess it depends on what is in the README
Maybe "Flamewar Room"
I think the most stars was 15 or so
Experimenting with using convore stars as a way of expressing "me too" :)

Though I'll repeat something I said elsewhere: I find Markdown > ReST for prose that doesn't require the sort of multi-document structure ReST provides. ReST makes headers, inline monospacing, and nested bulleted lists a much bigger PITA than they need to be.
sweet, i can star my own posts
i.e. once more than like 5-6 people have starred a comment
anyway, end derail, this is not the Convore Etiquette thread :D
@bitprophet facebook?
@bitprophet I like this idea!
I'm not on FB actually, but maybe it's from seeing screenshots of it. (people love to repost their wacky FB antics in funny-picture threads...sigh)
:D
how meta
@bitprophet Agreed.  I wonder how they'll handle that when it becomes a problem.  Maybe "bitphophet, kennethreitz, bmontgomery... and 5323 others"?
Nice :)
on a message I posted saying "star here if you're coming to an event"
@bkmontgomery I think it has merit, mostly because it shows the names of those starring. In "big" topics it'll break down pretty quickly though :(
Back on topic: While I DO like ReST and Markdown, I don't find Plain text annoying at all.
Feel free to create new topics :)
@bitprophet so far the stars have been self-limiting
@bitprophet yeah, facebook does that w/ their like system. "Liked by friend1, friend2, and 4.9 million others"
@leah OK, I must be remembering some other site then.
twitter too
convore too once kanye west starts a group
or Oprah has it on her show
Plain text is as simple as you can get. Plus it forces one to be as detailed as possible. (or it should) But I love me some Markdown.
I'm going to be the odd one and vote for org-mode. Like some other mentioned formats, it's just text, but also lets you export to HTML and TeX if you need fancier presentation.
I think it depends, if you're not doing anything fancy, then just plain text README can be fine.
I prefer restructured text, then again I use it for the documentation, docstrings and any other text.
+1 to restructured text, it's nice and quite simple to start, but has a lot of advanced features which can be handy
@kennethreitz https://github.com/github/markup/pull/37
Any relatively human-readable format is fine, as long as it's structured in some way. Textile, Markdown, Org, AsciiDoc, whatever. I personally use Textile.
markdown all the way
"We couldn't find a README for this repository" my ass
README.rb: https://github.com/judofyr/sexp_template/blob/master/README.rb
ASCII art in the readme FTW.
"Markdown for lyfe" (cit.)
@johnmangino How does it force you to be detailed? (if I dare reply to a month old message)
@chrisvest Gotta be honest. Not sure why I said that at the time.
disappointing, but not actively annoying. passively annoying.
